column10: De la Calancha tells of the destruction of the indigenous people of Anco Anco, who were scorched by fire and swallowed by the earth (pp. 513-517). The phenomenon narrated was explained by José de Acosta in 1590 (Historia natural y moral de las Indias) as the result of an earthquake. De la Calancha adds a moralising dimension to the narrative: the Indians were victims of God's punishment as sodomites and idolaters.

column10: A p. 501, Torres refers to the impossibility of evangelising the Indians of the Anco Anco settlement. This forced Father Contreras to leave the doctrine in the hands of the bishop in 1567, and subsequently justified the divine punishment: the earth opened up and swallowed the village. In this way, Torres continues the moralising explanation of the disappearance of the village already applied by Father Antonio de la Calancha, the Augustinian chronicler who preceded him. In fact, Torres recalls that Maestro Calancha had already explained the event in detail. Previously, the Jesuit José de Acosta had attributed the disappearance of the Anco Anco village to an earthquake in 1581.

column10: The Franciscan, like the Augustinian Antonio de la Calancha, narrates in a moral key the destruction of the indigenous village of Anco Anco (Ango Ango) by the earthquake of 1581 mentioned by José de Acosta in his Historia natural y moral de las Indias (Natural and Moral History of the Indies, 1590). The idolatrous and sorcerous Indians would have been punished for their refusal to convert, so the event should act as a reminder to stop their vices.

It recounts the loud warning noise that occurred before the earthquake that alerted people. Few people died even though the earthquake also caused a tsunami, as happened in Chile. On this occasion, Lima decided to name the Visitation of the Virgin to her cousin Saint Isabel as patron saint. From then on, a mass, sermon and procession take place every year on 2 July.

column10: The description of the eruption of Huaynaputina occupies pages 73-80 of the Augustinian work. Torres attributes the eruption to the sins of Arequipa and recalls that already in the past the inhabitants had suffered the wrath of God with the earthquake of 1587. He reflects on the causes of the event, which, having occurred during the rainy season, should have led him to believe that the cause was not natural but divine. He also mentions how some preachers, such as the Jesuit Alonso Ruiz, had prophesied God's imminent punishment. On the disaster, he says he consulted the texts of the Jesuit Martín del Río, Juan Solórzano Pereira and Antonio de la Calancha. The author describes the phases of the calamity and how the noise generated by the eruption was mistaken by the viceroy for a naval battle with English pirates. Of particular note is the definition of Huaynaputina as an Indian Vesuvius'. The work of the Society of Jesus and the Augustinians in assisting the population is particularly noteworthy.'
column16: Providence, John Carter Brown Library 1-SIZE BA657.T693c

column10: Diego de Córdoba y Salinas notes the premonitory preaching of Francisco Solano in Trujillo 15 years before the catastrophe and the announcement of the earthquake by San Valentín to the abbess of the convent of Santa Clara. He also describes the destruction of the monastery of Santa María La Gracia La Real, belonging to the order of Santa Clara, and the general effects of the earthquake, which caused 350 deaths. He also refers to the aftershocks, which were stronger than the first earthquake, and to the emotions that the disaster generated in the population.
column16: Madrid, Biblioteca Nacional de España R/14078

column8: Por Pedro Lacavalleria, en la calle de la Libreria
column10: The friar, who witnessed the earthquake, refers to the comet of December 1618 that would have announced the tremor (pp. 488-489). He recounts the effects of the earthquake on the topography, the sea and the buildings of the city. According to De La Calancha, it caused 350 deaths (p. 489). He praises the action of the Augustinians in contrast to other religious orders who decided to leave the city (pp. 489-490). The poor decided to appoint De La Calancha as their representative to prevent the city from being moved. De La Calancha claims that he succeeded in his mission despite having the viceroy and the Audiencias against him (pp. 498-499). De La Calancha also refers to a prodigy that occurred after the earthquake, but denies the disastrous consequences attributed to it by the population (p. 490). The Augustinian friar also narrates the salvation of the painter Leonardo de Jaramillo (pp. 493-494) and the transfer of the temple of the Virgin of Guadalupe and her image because of the earthquake (pp. 566-567).
column16: Seville, Biblioteca de la Universidad de Sevilla A 050/111

column10: Diego de Córdoba y Salinas witnessed the earthquake that took place at 12 a.m. He refers the miracle of Nuestra Señora del Milagro's image, located in the main chapel of the Franciscan convent in Lima. The image appeared with jointed hands in prayer as if asking for forgiveness and mercy for the city. Moreover, one day when the religious were praying to the Virgin, they saw the image turn and smile at them. The friar tells about the damages that the earthquake caused to the cathedral. The only intercession of the Virgin managed to avoid the complete destruction of Lima.

column6: Dell’incendio fattosi nel Vesuvio a XVI di dicembre MDCXXXI e delle sue cause ed effetti. Con la narrazione di quanto è seguito in esso per tutto marzo 1632, e con la storia di tutti gli altri incendii nel medesimo monte avvenuti. Discorrendosi infine delle acque, le quali in questa occasione hanno danneggiato le campagne, e di molte altre cose curiose. column4: Al santissimo martire Gianuario
column6: L’incendio del monte Vesuvio. Di Francesco Bernaudo al santissimo martire Gianuario. Diviso in due parti: nella prima si discorre degli effetti del detto incendio in cap. XX; nella seconda delle cagioni in cap. XXVIII. Con dimostrarsi il tempo che durerà il detto incendio, i rimedii che vi sarebbono per estinguerlo, i futuri mali che ne predice, e altre cose curiosissime come dal racconto de’ capitoli nella seguente facciata appare
column16: Rome, Biblioteca Nazionale Centrale MISC. Val.910.5

column4: All’illustrissimo signore don Pietro Giordano Orsino, dignissimo preside del Sac. Reg. Cons.
column6: L’opre stupende e maravigliosi eccessi dalla natura prodotti nel monte Vesuvio della città di Napoli, liberata per intercessione della beatissima Vergine e de’ gloriosi santi Gennaro, Tomaso e altri protettori. Con la narratione de tutti i danni occorsi così ne’ paesi convicini del monte come lontani, e delle terre destrutte, e de casi successi così in questa come nell’altre volte che è succeduto l’incendio presente, e del gran frutto cavato per l’anime dal zelo de prencipi ecclesiastici e secolari, del governo e opra de religiosi della città di Napoli. Raccolte dal sig. Francesco Ceraso per il corso di cinquantasei giorni dell’incendio, all’illustrissimo signore don Pietro Giordano Orsino, dignissimo preside del Sac. Reg. Cons. e protonotario del Regno di Napoli meritissimo
column16: Rome, Biblioteca Nazionale Centrale MISC. Val.911.4

column4: All’Eminentiss. e Reuerendiss. Prencipe IL SIG. CARDINAL’ANTONIO BARBERINO
column6: Canzone nell'incendio del Vesuvio; Scelta di poesie nell'incendio del Vesuvio del cardinale Urbano Giorgi
column16: Perugia, Biblioteca Augusta ANT  I.F 256      (3)
column18: I-1631-VE-028F / 1631 Vesuvius Eruption / Cherubs holding the Barberini Coat of Arms (This document includes)
column19: Le pagine recanti la canzone sono indicate come 30-35.
column21: Foto ottenuta dalla Biblioteca di Perugia. Per related:  (Sono inseriti in una corona d’alloro retta da dieci putti alati il titolo e i nomi dell’antologista (Urbano Giorgi), del suo protettore Giangirolamo II Acquaviva d’Aragona, e quello del cardinale Antonio Barberini. La corona è sovrastata dallo stemma con tre api della casata Barberini. Altre otto api si dispongono simmetricamente sullo sfondo. In basso a sinistra si legge 'Lucas Ciamberlanus Urbinas scolpivit'; in basso a destra 'Augustinus Tassi Invenit'.) VALE PER TUTTE LE CASELLE DI URBANO GIORGI

column10: It is a voluminous work by the well-known erudite and poet Giulio Cesare Capaccio (1552-1634), in which, in the form of a dialogue, an ideal Neapolitan citizen illustrates to an ideal 'foreigner' the antiquities and beauties of the city. It was printed in 1630, but was not distributed until 1634 with an 86-page appendix Incendio del Vesuvio, on the 1631 eruption.

column10: The friar narrates the death of some Franciscans during the earthquake that also caused the ruin of the monastery of San Francisco. The earthquake was a punishment for guilt and came at night without any warning, causing the death of more than a thousand people, the destruction of buildings and the ruin of animals.  Córdoba y Salinas also tells of the destruction of the cathedral of Santiago and the convent of the nuns of Santa Clara, under the rule of the Franciscans. Finally, he tells of the ruin of the archbishop's palace and the miraculous survival of Bishop Gaspar de Villarroel. The earthquake was foretold that same night by a nun from the Augustinian monastery who saw in the air a naked sword and a scourge threatening the city.
column16: Madrid, Biblioteca Nacional de España R/14078

On the death of some franciscans during the earthquake, see pp. 640-641.
On the ruin of San Francisco monastery and nuns from Santa Clara convent, see pp. 641 and 642.
On the guilty as the cause of the earthquake, see p. 641.
On the victims, see p. 641.
On the destruction of the cathedral, see p. 642.
On the destruction of archiepiscopal palace and Villarroel's miracle, see p. 642.
On the vision of the Augustinian nun from Concepción convent, see p. 642.

column10: On p. 23, Torres praises Bishop Villarroel's reconstruction of both the cathedral and the monastery of La Concepción, of Augustinian nuns.On pp. 37 and 39, there are references to the earthquake and its destructive effects on some buildings. On pp. 532-533, the author recounts the miraculous salvation of the Augustinian bishop Gaspar de Villarroel thanks to the intercession of St. Francisco Javier. He goes on to narrate the work of the bishop to attend to the material and spiritual needs of the faithful and to rebuild the cathedral. All this without having requested money from the king.

column10: On pp. 644 and 645, Córdoba y Salinas reports on the duration of the earthquake and the emotions it provoked in the population. He describes the acts of public penitence carried out by the secular and ecclesiastical chapter and by the various religious orders. The earthquake is presented as one of the omens heralding the Last Judgement.

column10: On pages 659-660, Torres narrates how, at the time his work was being printed, news had arrived from Chile of the earthquake and tsunami that had devastated the city of Concepcion and had also been felt in Santiago de Chile, where the cathedral collapsed. Few people died, only the most fragile, such as some old people and children. The tsunami ruined the royal storehouses where papers, weapons and supplies were kept. The tragedy was all the greater because it coincided with the rebellion of the Indians, which was put down by the Count of Alba, Viceroy of Peru, and by the governor.

column6: Istoria del monte Vesuvio divisata in due libri da d. Ignazio Sorrentino sacerdote secolare della Torre del Greco
column10: The book is dedicated to Celestino Galiani, promoter of Newtonian and Lockian ideas in southern Italy. In the first chapters, the author analyses the minerals erupted by the volcano in 1631, illustrates the theory of Vesuvius' submarine origin and the different composition of the gases ejected. The second part opens with a description of the 1660 eruption, then moves on to the numerous eruptions occurred between 1682 and 1733, which Sorrentino observed in person, reporting personal notes and experiences. The 1682 eruption is described at pages 117-122

column6: Istoria del monte Vesuvio divisata in due libri da d. Ignazio Sorrentino sacerdote secolare della Torre del Greco
column10: The book is dedicated to Celestino Galiani, promoter of Newtonian and Lockian ideas in southern Italy. In the first chapters, the author analyses the minerals erupted by the volcano in 1631, illustrates the theory of Vesuvius' submarine origin and the different composition of the gases ejected. The second part opens with a description of the 1660 eruption, then moves on to the numerous eruptions occurred between 1682 and 1733, which Sorrentino observed in person, reporting personal notes and experiences. The 1689 eruption is described at page 124

column6: Istoria del monte Vesuvio divisata in due libri da d. Ignazio Sorrentino sacerdote secolare della Torre del Greco
column10: The book is dedicated to Celestino Galiani, promoter of Newtonian and Lockian ideas in southern Italy. In the first chapters, the author analyses the minerals erupted by the volcano in 1631, illustrates the theory of Vesuvius' submarine origin and the different composition of the gases ejected. The second part opens with a description of the 1660 eruption, then moves on to the numerous eruptions occurred between 1682 and 1733, which Sorrentino observed in person, reporting personal notes and experiences. The 1694 eruption is described at pages 125-130
column16: Rome, Bibliotheca Hertziana Be 4015-3340 raro IV
column20: INTERPRETAZIONE→Osservazioni empiriche

column6: Carta, o diario que escribe d. Joseph Eusebio de Llano y Zapata, a su más venerado amigo, y docto correspondiente, el doctor don Ignacio Chirivoga y Daza, canónigo de la santa iglesia de Quito, en que con la mayor verdad, y crítica más segura le da cuenta de todo lo acaecido en esta capital de el Perú, desde el viernes 28 de octubre de 1746, quando experimentó su mayor ruina, con el grande movimiento de tierra, que  nundac a las diez, y media de la noche del mencionado día, hasta 16 de febrero de 1747, con una tabla en que se da el cálculo exacto de todo el número de temblores, que se han sentido en el  nundac, sucesso, que es lastimoso assumpto de este escrito, y juntamente le participa el estrago del presidio del Callao, y sus habitadores, con la  nundación del mar, que los tragó en la noche del primer terremoto

column6: Segunda parte del nunca visto conflito, que ha experimentado la gran Ciudad de Córdoba con el terremoto del día primero de noviembre del corriente de 1755 el que arruinó muchos de sus edificios, y principalmente la torre de la cathedral. Se declara haber padecido el mismo estrago la villa de Hornachuelos, la de Peña Flor (en la que el convento franciscano quedó todo quarteado, y el altar mayor sin poder servir), la de Palma, y la de Posadas, donde haviendo cogido una pared a un niño, le dexó ileso. Con otras noticias, que verá el discreto, y curioso lector

column6: Dolorosos threnos al fatal estrago, que en la península de España ocasionó el trágico sucesso de un lamentable terremoto , acaecido poco antes de las diez de la mañana día de todos santos primero de noviembre del presente año de 1755. Y se da incidente noticia de los daños que también hizo en los Reynos de Marruecos, Fez, y de otros continentes de África, como también de otros espantosos sucessos por los mismos tiempos , en varias partes del mundo acaecidos. Y por último se ponen los favorables remedios, que nos ha franqueado el piadoso cielo ,para precavernos, y librarnos de tan tremendos insultos, y de otras semejantes calamidades. Su autor el padre D.L.R.
column16: Barcelona, Universitat de Barcelona, Biblioteca de Reserva B-45/5/31-6

column6: Relación, y observaciones phísicas-mathemáticas, y morales sobre el general terremoto, y la irrupción del mar del día primero de noviembre de este año de 1755, que comprehendió a la ciudad, y gran puerto de Sta. María, y a toda la costa, y tierra firme del Reyno de Andalucía. Es una carta que escrivió a la muy illustre, y Real Academia de las Buenas Letras de la ciudad de Sevilla. Don Juan Luis Roche, académico de erudición de la misma Real Academia, socio de la Real Sociedad de Ciencias de Sevilla, académico de la Real Academia Portopolitana, y residente en la ciudad, y gran puerto de Santa Maria, en el Gremio, y Universidad de Mareantes, y Cargadores a las Indias

Segunda Parte. Lastimoso romance donde se declara el desgraciado fin que tuvo un desesperado hombre blasfemo, en la Cierra de Alcaraz, que por averle la langosta comido todos los trigos, y haverle dexado uno sin tocárselo, blasfemando contra Dios, fue, y le dio fuego, y la langosta se bolviá contra él, y le comió los hojos, y la carne, este año de 1756
